_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan-Executive Summary

Facility:  WinField United
Location:  1413 FM 2378
           Lubbock, TX  79407
Phone:     806-885-4678

1.     Facility Policy.

        The owners, management and employees of WinField United are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Lubbock County LEPC, and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.

2.     Facility Information.

       The Lubbock facility's primary covered process activity is the storage of fertilizers.  This activity includes processing of anhydrous ammonia by a third-party company called Blick's Phosphate Conversions, LLC.  Anhydrous ammonia is received and processed into 10-34-0 non-hazardous liquid fertilizer.  Processing is periodic and usually occurs in the Spring and Fall.  Ammonia mixing with phosphoric acid occurs in a T-reactor owned and operated by Blick's Phosphate Conversions, LLC.  Water is used as both a reaction feed material and product stabilizer.  The emergency procedures for Lubbock are coordinated with the Lubbock County LEPC.

       WinField United - Lubbock, TX  has taken the necessary steps to comply with accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  The only process that this RMP includes is the storage of anhydrous ammonia. The T-reactor process is done entirely by Blick's Phosphate Conversions, LLC; and their process is also covered by OSHA's Process Safety Management standard.

3.     Accidental Release Prevention Program

        The facility is in compliance with the provisions of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia" and the Texas state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia.  The requirements for the PSM and RMP programs are managed in

an electronic EHS management system which sends reminders for required tasks and records task completion. There is a robust inspection program by the facility with periodic inspections by the Corporate EHS team.

5.      Five-Year Accident History.

         There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, has THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage, or environmental damage.

6.       Emergency Action Plan.

          The facility has:

           a.     A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 
                   29 CFR 1910.38;

           b.     Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and 
                   Community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III 
                   (EPCRA).

           c.     If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility, 
                   the required response action is to evacuate the area of the spill and 
                   call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our
                   Emergency Action Plan.

7.       Planned Changes to Improve Safety.

          Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the conditions of this facility.  Improvements to the storage tanks and loading system are planned for 2022 such as additional pressure relief capacity and hose pull-away protection.
